t: Miriam*p and Aaron began to talk against Moses because of his Cushite wife, for he had married a Cushite.
“Has the Lord*s spoken only through Moses?” they asked. “Hasn’t he also spoken through us?” And the Lord*s heard this.
(Now*p Moses was a very humble man, more humble than anyone else on the face of the earth.)
At*p once the Lord*s said to Moses, Aaron and Miriam, “Come out to the tent of meeting, all three of you.” So the three of them went out.
Then the Lord*s came down in a pillar of cloud; he stood at the entrance to the tent and summoned Aaron and Miriam. When the two of them stepped forward,
he said, “Listen to my words: “When*pn there is a prophet among you, I,*ld the Lord,*s reveal myself to them in visions, I*ld speak to them in dreams.
But*ln this is not true of my servant Moses; he*ld is faithful in all my house.
With*ln him I speak face to face, clearly*ld and not in riddles; he*ld sees the form of the Lord.*s Why*ln then were you not afraid to*ld speak against my servant Moses?”
The*p anger of the Lord*s burned against them, and he left them.
When*p the cloud lifted from above the tent, Miriam’s skin was leprous —it became as white as snow. Aaron turned toward her and saw that she had a defiling skin disease,
and he said to Moses, “Please, my lord, I ask you not to hold against us the sin we have so foolishly committed.
Do not let her be like a stillborn infant coming from its mother’s womb with its flesh half eaten away.”
So*p Moses cried out to the Lord,*s “Please, God, heal her!”

The*p Lord*s replied to Moses, “If her father had spit in her face, would she not have been in disgrace for seven days? Confine her outside the camp for seven days; after that she can be brought back.”
So Miriam was confined outside the camp for seven days, and the people did not move on till she was brought back.
After*p that, the people left Hazeroth and encamped in the Desert of Paran.
